title: Doctors missing vape injuries because symptoms are the same as flu and pneumonia
text:
Jeffrey Manzanares was initially sent home with antibiotics but kept on feeling in pain (Picture: Reuters)

A 33-year-old man who went to hospital with vaping related injuries says he felt like ‘someone was stabbing a knife’ all over his body.

Jeffrey Manzanares is one of 22 patients treated from side effects of e-cigarettes amid a string of related deaths across the US.

Health officials are preparing to release new guidance stressing the need for doctors to ask every patient with an apparent respiratory infection about their vaping history.

Physicians will also be advised on how to diagnose and manage patients who may have both a lung infection and an injury caused by e-liquids.

There is often an overlap between the two, meaning many patients could slip through the net without a full diagnosis, the Centres for Disease Control (CDC) warns.

He ended up spending 17 days in intensive care after feeling like ‘someone was stabbing a knife’ across his body (Picture: Reuters)

Jeffrey was initially sent home with antibiotics and oxygen supplements for pneumonia triggered by a cold and human metapneumovirus.

This meant his vaping injury went undetected, meaning he was still left in agonising pain.

He added: ‘It felt like someone was stabbing a knife into my whole body.’

Jeffrey went to the University of Utah Hospital and ended up staying there for 21 days – 17 of which were in intensive care.

He says he lost 50 pounds (22.7 kg) during his illness – a third of his normal body weight.

Pulmonologist Dr Scott Aberegg said he was ‘wildly sick’ when he treated him.

Doctors warn many people could be slipping through the net because symptoms overlap with other respiratory illnesses (Picture: Reuters)

He added: ‘If that is any harbinger of what is to come in viral pneumonia season, this could be very problematic.’

Dr Aberegg took part in a conference call earlier this month with other doctors advising the CDC on how clinicians should diagnose and manage vaping patients.

He said many doctors who get back a positive flu test may just assume that is all the patient has and not realise they are also a vaper.

As of Tuesday, 1,299 people in the US have suffered from confirmed or probably cases of lung injuries linked to vaping, and 26 have died.

Some doctors have raised fears vaping injury cases will be missed in the crush of patients seeking treatment for seasonal flu and other respiratory ailments.

New advice is being issued advising doctors to ask respiratory patients about their vaping history (Picture: Reuters)

Common symptoms cased by e-cigarette use include shortness of breath, coughing, chest pain, fever, and in some cases nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.

But doctors warn all of those symptoms can result from flu and other respiratory infections including, which make it complicated for medical professionals.

Influenza can be deadly for people who already have other underlying illnesses.

As many as 72 per cent of the earliest vaping patients in Illinois and Wisconsin sought medical treatment in outpatient clinics and emergency rooms before doctors admitted them to hospital with severe lung injuries from vaping.

According to the New England Journal of Medicine, many were initially sent home with antibiotics and had to go back for oxygen supplements and steroids when those failed.

description: The US Centres for Disease Control (CDC) warns vaping injuries share symptoms with flu, influenza and other respiratory diseases.
